pull.title: net: Consistent checksum handling
pull.body:
In principle, the checksums of P2P packets are simply 4-byte blobs which are the first bytes of SHA256(SHA256(payload)).

Currently they are handled as little-endian 32-bit integers half of the time, as blobs the other half, sometimes copying the one to the other, resulting in somewhat confused code.

This PR changes the handling to be consistent both at packet creation and receiving, making it (I think) easier to understand.

repo.name: bitcoin
repo.description: Laanwj's Bitcoin Core fork - see README.md on "readme" branch

events.body: utACK 0a1229617d647d8d288f2afa3006d6a6a5d942a1. This inconsistency has bothered me before.

events.message:
net: Consistent checksum handling

In principle, the checksums of P2P packets are simply 4-byte blobs which
are the first four bytes of SHA256(SHA256(payload)).

Currently they are handled as little-endian 32-bit integers half of the
time, as blobs the other half, sometimes copying the one to the other,
resulting in somewhat confused code.

This PR changes the handling to be consistent both at packet creation
and receiving, making it (I think) easier to understand.

events.body:
I've slightly changed the error message to no longer mention nChecksum, as the name of the field changed and is not relevant for troubleshooting anyway:

```
2016-09-28 10:42:19.666628 ProcessMessages(ping, 8 bytes): CHECKSUM ERROR expected 7ef0ca62 was 12234556
```

In some later pull we'd likely want to move all these messages to the net debug category. I'm also going to add a test later that will actually exercise the P2P network error logic.

utACK 41e58faf043864a64a6db08a8df527fa5fd1ec5b
Any reason to keep `CHECKSUM_SIZE = sizeof(int)` (`protocol.h`) instead of just `CHECKSUM_SIZE = 4`?

> Any reason to keep `CHECKSUM_SIZE = sizeof(int)` (`protocol.h`) instead of just `CHECKSUM_SIZE = 4`?

Yes, I thought about that too, we **know** that the checksum is always four bytes and it shouldn't change based on what happens to be the architectures int type. WIll do.

Edit: Done. Also changed the SIZE_SIZE to be a fixed-size uint32_t the same go. We already use `WriteLE32` at the packet-construction side.

events.message:
net: Hardcode protocol sizes and use fixed-size types

The P2P network uses a fixed protocol, these sizes shouldn't change
based on what happens to be the architecture.

issue.title: Backport Bitcoin PR#8822: net: Consistent checksum handling
issue.body:
This is backport of Bitcoin PR bitcoin/bitcoin#8822.

This is the last PR I'm sending before `main.{h,cpp}` split.

The original PR description follows.
---
In principle, the checksums of P2P packets are simply 4-byte blobs which are the first bytes of SHA256(SHA256(payload)).

Currently they are handled as little-endian 32-bit integers half of the time, as blobs the other half, sometimes copying the one to the other, resulting in somewhat confused code.

This PR changes the handling to be consistent both at packet creation and receiving, making it (I think) easier to understand.

issue.title: Net cherries
issue.body:
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/8715 - net: only delete CConnman if it's been created
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9289 - net: drop boost::thread_group
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/8688 - Move static global randomizer seeds into CConnman
  * Removed all "KeyedNetworkGroup" changes. We use a different node eviction scheme.
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/8822 - net: Consistent checksum handling
  * Minor patching, the checksum creation was moved into FinalizeHeaders on our side.
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9045 - Hash P2P messages as they are received instead of at process-time
* https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9050 - net: make a few values immutable, and use deterministic randomness for the localnonce

git doesn't recognize that net_processing.cpp is renamed to main.cpp, so all changes in net_processing are manually applied

issue.title: [Net] Massive network refactoring and speedup
issue.body:
This is a combination of multiple upstream PRs focused on optimizing the P2P networking flow after the introduction of CConnman encapsulation, and a few older PRs that were previously missed to support the later optimizations. The PRs are as follows:

- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9037 - net: Add test-before-evict discipline to addrman
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/5151 - make CMessageHeader a dumb storage class
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6589 - log bytes recv/sent per command
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/8688 - Move static global randomizer seeds into CConnman
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9050 - net: make a few values immutable, and use deterministic randomness for the localnonce
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/8708 - net: have CConnman handle message sending
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9128 - net: Decouple CConnman and message serialization
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/8822 - net: Consistent checksum handling
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9441 - Net: Massive speedup. Net locks overhaul
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9609 - net: fix remaining net assertions
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9626 - Clean up a few CConnman cs_vNodes/CNode things
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9698 - net: fix socket close race
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/9708 - Clean up all known races/platform-specific UB at the time PR was opened
  - Excluded bitcoin@512731bed0782f10092de35a960153b17ecc11eb and bitcoin@d8f2b8a8c032b83a3bd90750e58abaeece7e34e7, to be done in a separate PR

comments.body: A size check of `hash.size() <=  CMessageHeader::CHECKSUM_SIZE` is probably a total overkill...
A compile-time assertion could be added... But I don't think there is any risk of someone increasing `CHECKSUM_SIZE` larger than 32 in practice.
are these the wrong way around? i.e. the expected checksum is supposed to be displayed before the "was"?
